review:
Alright, let's cut through the noise and get straight to the code: Zazelenimo is a high-signal, open-source dApp targeting participatory budgeting for urban greening, with a pilot in Split, Croatia. The project is built on Ethereum, leverages quadratic funding (QF), and integrates with OSS like Cometh Connect and Gitcoin's Allo Protocol. It's got a clear OSS ethos, a real-world government partner, and a roadmap that screams "let's scale this thing."

Strengths? The project is open-source to the core, with a public repo and a transparent build process. It's not just another DeFi clone—it's onboarding cities and citizens to Web3, abstracting away blockchain friction with passkey wallets and seamless UX. The QF mechanism is a proven model for maximizing community impact, and the local stewardship model is a nice touch for sustainability. Plus, the team has a track record with previous Gitcoin rounds and real municipal engagement—no vaporware here.

But let's not get lost in the green hype. Weaknesses? The impact is currently hyper-localized (Split), and while the roadmap talks about scaling, there's no hard evidence of traction beyond the pilot. The application is light on hard metrics: no user numbers, no transaction stats, no on-chain addresses for deployed contracts. The legal and compliance work is still "in progress," which is a red flag for anything touching public funds and government partners. And while the OSS contribution is real, the innovation is more in the application of existing primitives than in new protocol design.

Requested changes: Show me the numbers! I want to see user growth, transaction volume, and on-chain activity. Give me a concrete scaling plan—how do you go from Split to 10, 100, 1,000 cities? Nail down the legal/compliance framework and publish it. And if you're serious about OSS impact, document your integrations and upstream contributions to Allo, Cometh, etc. Max utility means max transparency and reproducibility.

Bottom line: Zazelenimo is a solid OSS dApp with real-world traction and a clear public good angle, but it needs to level up on metrics, scaling, and compliance to hit max impact. Ship fast, iterate, and show your work—let's see this go global, not just local.

strengths.title: Open-Source to the Core
strengths.description: The project is fully open-source, with a public repo and transparent development. This aligns perfectly with the round's OSS focus and maximizes reproducibility and community contribution.

strengths.title: Real-World Government Integration
strengths.description: Partnership with the City of Split demonstrates practical adoption of OSS in the public sector—a huge, under-tapped market for open-source impact.

strengths.title: User-Centric, Frictionless Onboarding
strengths.description: Passkey-based embedded wallets and seamless UX lower the barrier for non-crypto natives, maximizing potential user base and impact.

strengths.title: Quadratic Funding for Max Utility
strengths.description: QF ensures resources are allocated based on broad community support, not just deep pockets—this is a proven, high-utility mechanism for public goods.

weaknesses.title: Limited Current Scale
weaknesses.description: Impact is currently restricted to a single city (Split), with no hard evidence of broader adoption or scaling beyond the pilot.

weaknesses.title: Lack of Hard Metrics
weaknesses.description: The application is missing concrete data on user numbers, transaction volume, and on-chain activity—critical for evaluating real impact and scalability.

weaknesses.title: Incomplete Legal/Compliance Framework
weaknesses.description: Legal documentation and compliance processes are still in progress, which is risky for a project working with public funds and government partners.

changes.title: Publish Key Metrics
changes.description: Provide up-to-date user numbers, transaction volume, and on-chain activity to demonstrate traction and real-world impact.

changes.title: Concrete Scaling Roadmap
changes.description: Detail a step-by-step plan for expanding beyond Split, including target cities, partnerships, and technical scaling strategies.

changes.title: Finalize and Publish Legal/Compliance Docs
changes.description: Complete all legal and compliance documentation and make it publicly available to build trust and ensure replicability for other municipalities.

changes.title: Document OSS Integrations and Upstream Contributions
changes.description: Showcase how your work is contributing back to the OSS ecosystem—document integrations, pull requests, and any upstream improvements to Allo, Cometh, etc.
